Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery flat open vessel, probably a plate; top: black-figure serpent or Typhon with worn added red, overlapped by obscure painted decoration consisting of wavy line inside curving line; underside: black figure creature with scales and hair; cross-hatched lozenge as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: For parallels regarding shape and subject-matter, see An 95 in Corinth VII, Part II, p. 117, pl. 71.
See D. Callipolitis-Feytmans, 'Evolution du plat corinthien', BCH 86 (1962) 149, no. 9, dated to Early Corinthian.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B103.13)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 92, no. A122)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.117) (Phase 1)
